column1: Palm Harbor is a census-designated place and unincorporated community in Pinellas County
column2: Florida
column3: United States.  As of the 2016 American Community Survey

column1: Palm Harbor is located 35 kilometres (22 mi) north of downtown St. Petersburg and west of Tampa. It is a largely residential community with several concentrations of commerce. Downtown Palm Harbor
column2: north of Tampa Road between U.S. Highway 19 Alternate and Omaha Street hosts many small shops and eateries along with a handful of historic buildings. U.S. Highway 19
column3: a mile or two east of downtown
column4: offers access to higher concentrations of commerce
column5: with an array of national chain restaurants and retailers. One entrance to Innisbrook Resort and Golf Club
column6: a nationally regarded golf course and home of the PGA's Valspar Championship
column7: is found on U.S. 19 just north of Alderman Road.

column1: The historic downtown district of Palm Harbor
column2: at Florida Avenue and Alt. US 19 and CR 1
column3: has numerous festivals and craft fairs. Old Palm Harbor Main Streets
column6: hosts their signature event the first Friday of every month. "Palm Harbor's First Friday Celebrations" are a popular community event for youngsters and adults alike. There are rides and games for the children
column7: with opportunities to dine on food from the many local restaurants
column8: enjoy local artists and crafters displaying and selling their wares.  Annually
column9: the first Sunday in October marks when the "Taste of Palm Harbor" festival is held. The event is presented by the Palm Harbor Junior Women's Club with the proceeds benefiting their "Making a Difference" grants & scholarships program. The Taste of Palm Harbor traditionally offers live music and the tasting of samples from over 20 local restaurants
column10: many of which make seafood their specialty.

column1: Palm Harbor is an unincorporated part of Pinellas County. HB 183 - Town of Palm Harbor/Pinellas County
column2: from 2009
column3: was the most recent local bill that would have scheduled a referendum allowing Palm Harbor voters the opportunity to decide if they want to incorporate
column4: but the bill died in committee. Pinellas County legislators had voted on January 22
column6: to support a bill allowing voters in Palm Harbor to decide if they wanted their unincorporated community to become the county's 25th city. It passed over the objections of Pinellas County Commissioner Susan Latvala
column7: who said she was appearing in both her official capacity and as a Palm Harbor resident. The Legislature would have needed to first conduct a feasibility study to make sure cityhood made fiscal sense.In 1985
column8: the Pinellas County Board of County Commissioners enacted County Code 85-28
column9: which set into place the Palm Harbor Community Services Agency (PHCSA)
column10: a special taxing district to which tax was levied in the form of millage to provide for recreational and library services to the unincorporated community. The PHCSA board is a volunteer panel elected by the voters within the district to oversee the funding of Palm Harbor Library
column11: East Lake Community Library and Palm Harbor Parks & Recreation.

column1: Palm Harbor has various recreational amenities. The area is home to John Chesnut
column2: Sr. Park
column3: located in the East Lake region
column4: as well as H.S. "Pop" Stansell Park
column5: located to the west of Palm Harbor Boulevard and overlooking St. Joseph's Sound. The Palm Harbor Community Services District also manages several sport complexes in the community: Steve Putnam Park
column7: and Sunderman Recreation Complex. The community activity center is located at 1500 16th Street
column8: managed by the District's parks and recreation department. This facility was originally constructed by Pinellas County in the late 1990s as a senior recreation facility
column9: however lacked the funding to remain open and available to the community. The District received the property in 2004
column12: youth summer camps and community services.Palm Harbor is also the home to the White Chapel. This historic facility
column13: which was under Pinellas County ownership previously
column14: lacked the funding to keep its doors opened and was given to the Palm Harbor Community Services District in November 2012. Now managed by the District's parks and recreation department
column15: the Chapel was completely restored and is the site for many banquets
column16: weddings and community special events. Harbor Hall
column17: the banquet facility built next to the Chapel
column18: also serves as a banquet and recreational space.

column2: -82.753947).According to the United States Census Bureau
column3: the CDP has a total area of 26.6 square miles (68.9 km2)
column4: of which  17.4 square miles (45.0 km2) is land
column5: and 9.2 square miles (23.9 km2) (34.67%) is water.Palm Harbor has a unique "hilly" geography which is uncommon in Florida.

column1: Palm Harbor was originally called Sutherland
column2: a shortening of Southern Land and Development Company
column3: the group that originally platted the community as Sutherland
column5: in 1888.  The name was changed to Palm Harbor in 1925. Palm Harbor was originally settled by area pioneers including the Thompsons ca 1865
column16: the Aldermans and the Wilsons. J.C. Craver was the first Northerner to permanently settle in this portion of Hillsborough County. According to Craver's diary
column18: he came here in the winter of 1877 upon the advice of his physician. A post office commission under the name of Bay St. Joseph was granted in 1878
column19: this being the earliest written record of the community. The name Bay St. Joseph was used only a short time before Yellow Bluff replaced it. But that name proved relatively short-lived
column20: as a few years later its negative connotation with the yellow fever epidemic gave way to its present name. Palm Harbor was originally called Sutherland after a post office was granted in 1888
column21: the same year the railroad came through. Sutherland boasted two beautiful hotels
column22: the larger one becoming Southern College in 1902. It sat high on the bluff overlooking Sutherland Bayou and the Gulf of Mexico. Sutherland was thought to be named after the Duke of Sutherland
column23: who visited these parts after landing at Tarpon Springs in 1887. Local pioneers dismiss this coincidence
column24: pointing out that the name Sutherland is a shortening of Southern Land and Development Company
column25: the group which originally platted the community in 1888.
